an7.58:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa arakkheyyāni, tīhi ca anupavajjo.
an7.58:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide, and three ways he is irreproachable.

an7.58:1.2.eng: What are the four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide?

an7.58:1.4.pli: natthi tathāgatassa kāyaduccaritaṃ yaṃ tathāgato rakkheyya:
an7.58:1.4.eng: So the Realized One has no bodily misconduct to hide, thinking:

an7.58:1.5.eng: ‘Don’t let others find this out about me!’

an7.58:2.2.pli: natthi tathāgatassa vacīduccaritaṃ yaṃ tathāgato rakkheyya:
an7.58:2.2.eng: So the Realized One has no verbal misconduct to hide, thinking:

an7.58:2.3.eng: ‘Don’t let others find this out about me!’

an7.58:3.2.pli: natthi tathāgatassa manoduccaritaṃ yaṃ tathāgato rakkheyya:
an7.58:3.2.eng: So the Realized One has no mental misconduct to hide, thinking:

an7.58:3.3.eng: ‘Don’t let others find this out about me!’

an7.58:4.2.pli: natthi tathāgatassa micchāājīvo yaṃ tathāgato rakkheyya:
an7.58:4.2.eng: So the Realized One has no wrong livelihood to hide, thinking:

an7.58:4.3.eng: ‘Don’t let others find this out about me!’

an7.58:5.1.eng: These are the four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide.

an7.58:6.1.eng: What are the three ways the Realized One is irreproachable?

an7.58:6.2.eng: The Realized One has explained the teaching well.

an7.58:6.3.pli: Tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessati:
an7.58:6.3.eng: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying:

an7.58:6.4.eng: ‘For such and such reasons you haven’t explained the teaching well.’

an7.58:6.6.pli: Etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
an7.58:6.6.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

an7.58:7.1.pli: Supaññattā kho pana me, bhikkhave, sāvakānaṃ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā.
an7.58:7.1.eng: I have clearly described the practice that leads to extinguishment for my disciples.

an7.58:7.2.pli: Yathāpaṭipannā mama sāvakā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
an7.58:7.2.eng: Practicing in accordance with this, my disciples realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.58:7.3.pli: Tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessati:
an7.58:7.3.eng: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying:

an7.58:7.4.pli: ‘itipi te na supaññattā sāvakānaṃ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā. Yathāpaṭipannā tava sāvakā āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī’ti.
an7.58:7.4.eng: ‘For such and such reasons you haven’t clearly described the practice that leads to extinguishment for your disciples.’

an7.58:7.6.pli: Etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
an7.58:7.6.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

an7.58:8.1.pli: Anekasatā kho pana me, bhikkhave, sāvakaparisā āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
an7.58:8.1.eng: Many hundreds in my assembly of disciples have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an7.58:8.2.pli: Tatra vata maṃ samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā devo vā māro vā brahmā vā koci vā lokasmiṃ sahadhammena paṭicodessati:
an7.58:8.2.eng: I see no reason for anyone—whether ascetic, brahmin, god, Māra, or the Divinity, or anyone else in the world—to legitimately scold me, saying:

an7.58:8.3.pli: ‘itipi te na anekasatā sāvakaparisā āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī’ti.
an7.58:8.3.eng: ‘For such and such reasons you don’t have many hundreds of disciples in your following who have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and who live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an7.58:8.5.pli: Etamahaṃ, bhikkhave, nimittaṃ asamanupassanto khemappatto abhayappatto vesārajjappatto viharāmi.
an7.58:8.5.eng: Since I see no such reason, I live secure, fearless, and assured.

an7.58:9.1.eng: These are the three ways the Realized One is irreproachable.

an7.58:10.1.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri tathāgatassa arakkheyyāni, imehi ca tīhi anupavajjo”ti.
an7.58:10.1.eng: These are the four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide, and the three ways he is irreproachable.”

an7.59:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kimilāyaṃ viharati niculavane.
an7.59:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kimbilā in the Freshwater Mangrove Wood.

an7.59:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā kimilo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā kimilo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.59:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Kimbila went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an7.59:1.4.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti?
an7.59:1.4.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?”

an7.59:2.1.pli: “Idha, kimila, tathāgate parinibbute bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo satthari agāravā viharanti appatissā, dhamme agāravā viharanti appatissā, saṅghe agāravā viharanti appatissā, sikkhāya agāravā viharanti appatissā, samādhismiṃ agāravā viharanti appatissā, appamāde agāravā viharanti appatissā, paṭisanthāre agāravā viharanti appatissā.
an7.59:2.1.eng: “Kimbila, it’s when the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen lack respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, immersion, diligence, and hospitality after the final quenching of the Realized One.

an7.59:2.2.pli: Ayaṃ kho, kimila, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo na ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti.
an7.59:2.2.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why the true teaching does not last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.”

an7.59:3.1.pli: “Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti?
an7.59:3.1.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One?”

an7.59:3.2.pli: “Idha, kimila, tathāgate parinibbute bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo satthari sagāravā viharanti sappatissā, dhamme sagāravā viharanti sappatissā, saṅghe sagāravā viharanti sappatissā, sikkhāya sagāravā viharanti sappatissā, samādhismiṃ sagāravā viharanti sappatissā, appamāde sagāravā viharanti sappatissā, paṭisanthāre sagāravā viharanti sappatissā.
an7.59:3.2.eng: “Kimbila, it’s when the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen maintain respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, immersion, diligence, and hospitality after the final quenching of the Realized One.

an7.59:3.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho, kimila, hetu ayaṃ paccayo yena tathāgate parinibbute saddhammo ciraṭṭhitiko hotī”ti.
an7.59:3.3.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why the true teaching does last long after the final quenching of the Realized One.”

an7.6:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven kinds of wealth.

an7.6:1.3.pli: Saddhādhanaṃ, sīladhanaṃ, hirīdhanaṃ, ottappadhanaṃ, sutadhanaṃ, cāgadhanaṃ, paññādhanaṃ.
an7.6:1.3.eng: The wealth of faith, ethics, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

an7.6:2.1.eng: And what is the wealth of faith?

an7.6:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saddho hoti, saddahati tathāgatassa bodhiṃ:
an7.6:2.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening …

an7.6:2.3.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho …pe… buddho bhagavā’ti.

an7.6:2.4.eng: This is called the wealth of faith.

an7.6:3.1.eng: And what is the wealth of ethical conduct?

an7.6:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe… surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
an7.6:3.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an7.6:3.3.eng: This is called the wealth of ethical conduct.

an7.6:4.1.eng: And what is the wealth of conscience?

an7.6:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako hirīmā hoti, hirīyati kāyaduccaritena vacīduccaritena manoduccaritena, hirīyati pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā.
an7.6:4.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has a conscience. They’re conscientious about bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and conscientious about having any bad, unskillful qualities.

an7.6:4.3.eng: This is called the wealth of conscience.

an7.6:5.1.eng: And what is the wealth of prudence?

an7.6:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako ottappī hoti, ottappati kāyaduccaritena vacīduccaritena manoduccaritena, ottappati pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā.
an7.6:5.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is prudent. They’re prudent when it comes to bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and prudent when it comes to the acquiring of any bad, unskillful qualities.

an7.6:5.3.eng: This is called the wealth of prudence.

an7.6:6.1.eng: And what is the wealth of learning?

an7.6:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti. Tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti dhātā vacasā paricitā manasānupekkhitā diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
an7.6:6.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.

an7.6:6.3.eng: This is called the wealth of learning.

an7.6:7.1.eng: And what is the wealth of generosity?

an7.6:7.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vosaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
an7.6:7.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an7.6:7.3.eng: This is called the wealth of generosity.

an7.6:8.1.eng: And what is the wealth of wisdom?

an7.6:8.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako paññavā hoti …pe… sammā dukkhakkhayagāminiyā.
an7.6:8.2.eng: It’s when a noble disciple is wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.

an7.6:8.3.eng: This is called the wealth of wisdom.

an7.6:9.1.eng: These are the seven kinds of wealth.

an7.6:10.1.eng: Faith and ethical conduct are kinds of wealth,

an7.6:10.4.eng: and wisdom is the seventh kind of wealth.

an7.6:11.4.eng: their life is not in vain.

an7.6:12.1.eng: So let the wise devote themselves

an7.6:12.3.eng: confidence, and insight into the teaching,

an7.6:12.4.eng: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.”

an7.60:1.1.pli: “Sattahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nacirasseva āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyya.
an7.60:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with seven qualities soon realizes the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. They live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an7.60:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddho hoti, sīlavā hoti, bahussuto hoti, paṭisallīno hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, satimā hoti, paññavā hoti.
an7.60:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is faithful, ethical, learned, secluded, energetic, mindful, and wise.

an7.60:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, sattahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu nacirasseva āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā”ti.
an7.60:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these seven qualities soon realizes the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. They live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

an7.61:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
an7.61:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

an7.61:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahāmoggallāno magadhesu kallavāḷaputtagāme pacalāyamāno nisinno hoti.
an7.61:1.3.eng: Now at that time, in the land of the Magadhans near Kallavāḷamutta Village, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was nodding off while meditating.

an7.61:1.4.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ magadhesu kallavāḷaputtagāme pacalāyamānaṃ nisinnaṃ.
an7.61:1.4.eng: The Buddha saw him with his clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman.

an7.61:1.6.pli: seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—bhaggesu susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye antarahito magadhesu kallavāḷaputtagāme āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
an7.61:1.6.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood in the land of the Bhaggas and reappeared in front of Mahāmoggallāna near Kallavāḷamutta Village in the land of the Magadhans.

an7.61:1.7.eng: He sat on the seat spread out

an7.61:1.8.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca:

an7.61:2.1.pli: “Pacalāyasi no tvaṃ, moggallāna, pacalāyasi no tvaṃ, moggallānā”ti?
an7.61:2.1.eng: “Are you nodding off, Moggallāna? Are you nodding off?”

an7.61:2.3.pli: “Tasmātiha, moggallāna, yathāsaññissa te viharato taṃ middhaṃ okkamati, taṃ saññaṃ mā manasākāsi, taṃ saññaṃ mā bahulamakāsi.
an7.61:2.3.eng: “So, Moggallāna, don’t focus on or cultivate the perception that you were meditating on when you fell drowsy.

an7.61:2.4.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, moggallāna, vijjati yaṃ te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha.
an7.61:2.4.eng: It’s possible that you’ll give up drowsiness in this way.

an7.61:3.1.pli: No ce te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha, tato tvaṃ, moggallāna, yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ cetasā anuvitakkeyyāsi anuvicāreyyāsi, manasā anupekkheyyāsi.
an7.61:3.1.eng: But what if that doesn’t work? Then think about and consider the teaching as you’ve learned and memorized it, examining it with your mind.

an7.61:3.2.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha.
an7.61:3.2.eng: It’s possible that you’ll give up drowsiness in this way.

an7.61:4.1.pli: No ce te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha, tato tvaṃ, moggallāna, yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattaṃ dhammaṃ vitthārena sajjhāyaṃ kareyyāsi.
an7.61:4.1.eng: But what if that doesn’t work? Then rehearse in detail the teaching as you’ve learned and memorized it.

an7.61:4.2.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha.
an7.61:4.2.eng: It’s possible that you’ll give up drowsiness in this way.

an7.61:5.1.pli: No ce te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha, tato tvaṃ, moggallāna, ubho kaṇṇasotāni āviñcheyyāsi, pāṇinā gattāni anumajjeyyāsi.
an7.61:5.1.eng: But what if that doesn’t work? Then pinch your ears and rub your limbs.

an7.61:5.2.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha.
an7.61:5.2.eng: It’s possible that you’ll give up drowsiness in this way.

an7.61:6.1.pli: No ce te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha, tato tvaṃ, moggallāna, uṭṭhāyāsanā udakena akkhīni anumajjitvā disā anuvilokeyyāsi, nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni ullokeyyāsi.
an7.61:6.1.eng: But what if that doesn’t work? Then get up from your seat, flush your eyes with water, look around in every direction, and look up at the stars and constellations.

an7.61:6.2.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha.
an7.61:6.2.eng: It’s possible that you’ll give up drowsiness in this way.

an7.61:7.1.pli: No ce te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha, tato tvaṃ, moggallāna, ālokasaññaṃ manasi kareyyāsi, divāsaññaṃ adhiṭṭhaheyyāsi—
an7.61:7.1.eng: But what if that doesn’t work? Then apply your mind to the perception of light, focusing on the perception of day:

an7.61:7.2.pli: yathā divā tathā rattiṃ yathā rattiṃ tathā divā.
an7.61:7.2.eng: as by day, so by night; as by night, so by day.

an7.61:7.3.pli: Iti vivaṭena cetasā apariyonaddhena sappabhāsaṃ cittaṃ bhāveyyāsi.
an7.61:7.3.eng: And so, with an open and unenveloped heart, develop a mind that’s full of radiance.

an7.61:7.4.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha.
an7.61:7.4.eng: It’s possible that you’ll give up drowsiness in this way.

an7.61:8.1.pli: No ce te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha, tato tvaṃ, moggallāna, pacchāpuresaññī caṅkamaṃ adhiṭṭhaheyyāsi antogatehi indriyehi abahigatena mānasena.
an7.61:8.1.eng: But what if that doesn’t work? Then walk mindfully, focusing on the perception of before and behind, your faculties directed inwards and your mind not scattered outside.

an7.61:8.2.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha.
an7.61:8.2.eng: It’s possible that you’ll give up drowsiness in this way.

an7.61:9.1.pli: No ce te evaṃ viharato taṃ middhaṃ pahīyetha, tato tvaṃ, moggallāna, dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappeyyāsi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasi karitvā.
an7.61:9.1.eng: But what if that doesn’t work? Then lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.

an7.61:9.2.pli: Paṭibuddhena ca te, moggallāna, khippaññeva paccuṭṭhātabbaṃ:
an7.61:9.2.eng: When you wake, you should get up quickly, thinking:

an7.61:9.3.pli: ‘na seyyasukhaṃ na passasukhaṃ na middhasukhaṃ anuyutto viharissāmī’ti.
an7.61:9.3.eng: ‘I will not live indulging in the pleasures of sleeping, lying down, and drowsing.’

an7.61:10.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an7.61:10.2.eng: ‘I will not approach families with my head swollen with vanity.’

an7.61:10.4.pli: Sace, moggallāna, bhikkhu uccāsoṇḍaṃ paggahetvā kulāni upasaṅkamati, santi hi, moggallāna, kulesu kiccakaraṇīyāni.
an7.61:10.4.eng: What happens if a mendicant approaches families with a head swollen with vanity? Well, families have business to attend to,

an7.61:10.5.pli: Yehi manussā āgataṃ bhikkhuṃ na manasi karonti, tatra bhikkhussa evaṃ hoti:
an7.61:10.5.eng: so people might not notice when a mendicant arrives. In that case the mendicant thinks:

an7.61:10.6.pli: ‘kosu nāma idāni maṃ imasmiṃ kule paribhindi, virattarūpā dānime mayi manussā’ti.
an7.61:10.6.eng: ‘Who on earth has turned this family against me? It seems they don’t like me any more.’

an7.61:10.7.pli: Itissa alābhena maṅkubhāvo, maṅkubhūtassa uddhaccaṃ, uddhatassa asaṃvaro, asaṃvutassa ārā cittaṃ samādhimhā.
an7.61:10.7.eng: And so, because they don’t get anything they feel dismayed. Being dismayed, they become restless. Being restless, they lose restraint. And without restraint the mind is far from immersion.

an7.61:11.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an7.61:11.4.pli: Viggāhikāya, moggallāna, kathāya sati kathābāhullaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ, kathābāhulle sati uddhaccaṃ, uddhatassa asaṃvaro, asaṃvutassa ārā cittaṃ samādhimhā.
an7.61:11.4.eng: When there’s an argument, you can expect there’ll be lots of talking. When there’s lots of talking, people become restless. Being restless, they lose restraint. And without restraint the mind is far from immersion.

an7.61:11.5.eng: Moggallāna, I don’t praise all kinds of closeness.

an7.61:11.6.pli: Na panāhaṃ, moggallāna, sabbeheva saṃsaggaṃ na vaṇṇayāmi.
an7.61:11.6.eng: Nor do I criticize all kinds of closeness.

an7.61:11.7.pli: Sagahaṭṭhapabbajitehi kho ahaṃ, moggallāna, saṃsaggaṃ na vaṇṇayāmi.
an7.61:11.7.eng: I don’t praise closeness with laypeople and renunciates.

an7.61:11.8.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni senāsanāni appasaddāni appanigghosāni vijanavātāni manussarāhasseyyakāni paṭisallānasāruppāni tathārūpehi senāsanehi saṃsaggaṃ vaṇṇayāmī”ti.
an7.61:11.8.eng: I do praise closeness with those lodgings that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.”

an7.61:12.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an7.61:12.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Moggallāna asked the Buddha,

an7.61:12.2.pli: “kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti?
an7.61:12.2.eng: “Sir, how do you briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans?”

an7.61:13.3.eng: When a mendicant has heard that

an7.61:13.5.pli: So sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhijānāti, sabbaṃ dhammaṃ abhiññāya sabbaṃ dhammaṃ parijānāti. Sabbaṃ dhammaṃ pariññāya yaṃ kiñci vedanaṃ vediyati sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā.
an7.61:13.5.eng: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Completely understanding all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—

an7.61:13.6.pli: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
an7.61:13.6.eng: they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings.

an7.61:13.7.pli: So tāsu vedanāsu aniccānupassī viharanto virāgānupassī viharanto nirodhānupassī viharanto paṭinissaggānupassī viharanto na kiñci loke upādiyati,
an7.61:13.7.eng: Meditating in this way, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.

an7.61:13.8.pli: anupādiyaṃ na paritassati, aparitassaṃ paccattaṃyeva parinibbāyati.
an7.61:13.8.eng: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.

an7.61:13.9.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
an7.61:13.9.eng: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’

an7.61:13.10.pli: Ettāvatā kho, moggallāna, bhikkhu saṅkhittena taṇhāsaṅkhayavimutto hoti accantaniṭṭho accantayogakkhemī accantabrahmacārī accantapariyosāno seṭṭho devamanussānan”ti.
an7.61:13.10.eng: That’s how I briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans.”

an7.615:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, for insight into greed, seven things should be developed.

an7.615:1.5.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime satta dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an7.615:1.5.eng: These seven things should be developed for insight into greed.”

an7.616:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, for insight into greed, seven things should be developed.

an7.616:1.3.pli: Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā—
an7.616:1.3.eng: The perception of impermanence, the perception of not-self, the perception of ugliness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation.

an7.616:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime satta dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an7.616:1.4.eng: These seven things should be developed for insight into greed.”

an7.617:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, for insight into greed, seven things should be developed.

an7.617:1.3.pli: Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā—
an7.617:1.3.eng: The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering.

an7.617:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime satta dhammā bhāvetabbā”ti.
an7.617:1.4.eng: These seven things should be developed for insight into greed.”

an7.618-644:1.9.eng: For the letting go of greed, these seven things should be developed.”

an7.62:1.2.eng: For ‘good deeds’ is a term for happiness.

an7.62:1.3.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, dīgharattaṃ katānaṃ puññānaṃ dīgharattaṃ iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpaṃ vipākaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ.
an7.62:1.3.eng: I recall undergoing for a long time the likable, desirable, and agreeable results of good deeds performed over a long time.

an7.62:1.4.eng: I developed a mind of love for seven years.

an7.62:1.5.pli: Satta vassāni mettacittaṃ bhāvetvā satta saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe nayimaṃ lokaṃ punāgamāsiṃ.
an7.62:1.5.eng: As a result, for seven eons of the cosmos contracting and expanding I didn’t return to this world again.

an7.62:1.6.pli: Saṃvaṭṭamāne sudāhaṃ, bhikkhave, loke ābhassarūpago homi,
an7.62:1.6.eng: As the cosmos contracted I went to the realm of streaming radiance.

an7.62:1.7.eng: As it expanded I was reborn in an empty mansion of divinity.

an7.62:2.1.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, brahmā homi mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī.
an7.62:2.1.eng: There I was the Divinity, the Great Divinity, the vanquisher, the unvanquished, the universal seer, the wielder of power.

an7.62:2.2.pli: Chattiṃsakkhattuṃ kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sakko ahosiṃ devānamindo;
an7.62:2.2.eng: I was Sakka, lord of gods, thirty-six times.

an7.62:2.3.pli: anekasatakkhattuṃ rājā ahosiṃ cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
an7.62:2.3.eng: Many hundreds of times I was a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. My dominion extended to all four sides, I achieved stability in the country, and I possessed the seven treasures.

an7.62:2.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhikkhave, imāni satta ratanāni ahesuṃ, seyyathidaṃ—

an7.62:2.5.pli: cakkaratanaṃ, hatthiratanaṃ, assaratanaṃ, maṇiratanaṃ, itthiratanaṃ, gahapatiratanaṃ, pariṇāyakaratanameva sattamaṃ.
an7.62:2.5.eng: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.

an7.62:2.6.pli: Parosahassaṃ kho pana me, bhikkhave, puttā ahesuṃ sūrā vīraṅgarūpā parasenappamaddanā.
an7.62:2.6.eng: I had over a thousand sons who were valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of my enemies.

an7.62:2.7.pli: So imaṃ pathaviṃ sāgarapariyantaṃ adaṇḍena asatthena dhammena abhivijiya ajjhāvasinti.
an7.62:2.7.eng: After conquering this land girt by sea, I reigned by principle, without rod or sword.

an7.62:3.1.eng: See the result of good deeds,

an7.62:3.2.eng: of skillful deeds, for one seeking happiness.

an7.62:3.3.eng: I developed a mind of love

an7.62:3.5.eng: For seven eons of expansion and contraction

an7.62:3.6.eng: I didn’t return to this world again.

an7.62:4.2.eng: I went to the realm of streaming radiance.

an7.62:4.4.eng: I went to an empty mansion of divinity.

an7.62:5.1.eng: Seven times I was a Great Divinity,

an7.62:5.2.eng: and at that time I was the wielder of power.

an7.62:5.3.eng: Thirty-six times I was lord of gods,

an7.62:5.4.eng: acting as ruler of the gods.

an7.62:6.1.eng: Then I was king, a wheel-turning monarch,

an7.62:6.2.eng: lord of the Black Plum Tree Land.

an7.62:6.4.eng: I was sovereign of all humans.

an7.62:8.3.eng: I was born in a rich family,

an7.62:9.1.eng: It was replete with all sense pleasures,

an7.62:9.3.eng: This was well taught by the Buddhas,

an7.62:10.1.eng: This is the cause of greatness

an7.62:10.2.eng: by which one is called a lord of the land.

an7.62:10.4.eng: with lots of property and assets.

an7.62:11.2.eng: lord of the Black Plum Tree Land.

an7.62:11.3.eng: Who would not be inspired by this,

an7.62:12.4.eng: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.”
